source.fb0caa02:
data['Home Shot Accuracy'] = data.loc[:, 'Home Team On Target Shots']/ data.loc[:,'Home Team Total Shots'] *100
data['Away Shot Accuracy'] = data.loc[:, 'Away Team On Target Shots']/ data.loc[:,'Away Team Total Shots'] *100
source.75cbbd56:
data['Home Goal Accuracy'] = data.loc[:, 'Home Team Goals Scored']/ data.loc[:,'Home Team Total Shots'] *100
data['Away Goal Accuracy'] = data.loc[:, 'Away Team Goals Scored']/ data.loc[:,'Away Team Total Shots'] *100
source.2f524b4e:
data['Home GK Save Rate'] = (data.loc[:, 'Away Team Total Shots']-data.loc[:, 'Away Team Goals Scored'])/ data.loc[:,'Away Team Total Shots'] *100
data['Away GK Save Rate'] = (data.loc[:, 'Home Team Total Shots']-data.loc[:, 'Home Team Goals Scored'])/ data.loc[:,'Home Team Total Shots'] *100

fig.show()
source.4c574785:
from plotly.subplots import make_subplots
import plotly.graph_objects as go

fig = make_subplots(rows=1, cols=2)

fig.add_trace(
    go.Scatter(x=a1['Home Team Pass Success %'].mean().index, y=a1['Home Team Pass Success %'].mean(), name='Home Team Pass Success %'),
    row=1, col=1
)

fig.add_trace(
    go.Scatter(x=a1['Away Team Pass Success %'].mean().index, y=a1['Away Team Pass Success %'].mean(), name='Away Team Pass Success %'),
    row=1, col=2
)
fig.update_layout(height=600, width=1000, title_text="Home Team Pass Success % vs Away Team Pass Success %")
fig.show()

source.1c102ff4:
english = data[data['league'] == 'english']
english1 = english.groupby('year')
french = data[data['league'] == 'french']
german = data[data['league'] == 'german']
italian = data[data['league'] == 'italian']
spanish = data[data['league'] == 'spanish']
french1 = french.groupby('year')
spanish1 = spanish.groupby('year')
italian1 = italian.groupby('year')
german1 = german.groupby('year')
source.e797528d:
fig3 = make_subplots(rows=5, cols=1)

fig3.add_trace(
    go.Scatter(x=english1['Match Excitement'].mean().index, y=english1['Match Excitement'].mean(), name='english Match Excitement'),
    row=1, col=1
)
fig3.add_trace(
    go.Scatter(x=french1['Match Excitement'].mean().index, y=french1['Match Excitement'].mean(), name='french Match Excitement'),
    row=2, col=1
)

    go.Scatter(x=spanish1['Match Excitement'].mean().index, y=spanish1['Match Excitement'].mean(), name='spanish Match Excitement'),
    row=3, col=1
)

    row=4, col=1
)

    go.Scatter(x=german1['Match Excitement'].mean().index, y=german1['Match Excitement'].mean(), name='german Match Excitement'),
    row=5, col=1
)
fig3.update_layout(height=1000, width=1000, title_text="Match Excitement")
fig3.show()

source.7a3882e3: ## Using the playing conditions to your advantage
source.0e747087: # Home Team Goals Scored vs Away Team Goals Scored
source.ee4fc3c8:
shot accuracy % = shots on target / total shots(shots on + shots off) * 100
shot goal accuracy % = goals/ total shots(shots on + shots off) *100
gk save rate = (shots on target - goals) / shots on target * 100
source.7276a7d2: # Home Team Fouls Vs Away Team Fouls
source.a06909ce:
Are you on the home side? Best seats in the house! The 'crowd factor' for the away team is just non existent.

Take a look at Old Trafford (stadium capacity of ~76,000). This best illustrates the home advantage. The hatched area tucked into a corner is where the away fans sit. A measly 3000 seats, approximately. That's 4% of the capacity!
source.7027f5b8: # # Data Visualization WRT  Different Leagues and Different Years
source.e6380a8e: # Home Team Goals Scored vs Away Team Goals Scored
source.bdbd6346: # Home Team Pass Success % vs Away Team Pass Success %
source.4880c356: # Home Team Pass Success % vs Away Team Pass Success %
source.bbed3a97: Imagine you're walking onto a pitch. You can already hear the crowd, your crowd, cheering for you. Tens of thousands of them. All in one voice. Every good pass is greeted with applause, every shot on target with appreciative claps and every goal with celebrations. Oh, wait, you're just the opposition-- 11 players that find themselves on the pitch observing this phenomenon. Where is your support? Why are you so alone? When will this end? Okay, maybe this is a bit of an exaggeration. Players are too professional these days to let this get to their heads... or are they?!
source.e9699b3c: # Home Team Red Cards vs Away Team Red Cards
source.3a7b82ed: # Home Team Shot Accuracy vs Away Team Shot Accuracy
source.7e5beffa:
Any referee, no matter how good, is influenced by the crowd. (They are human, after all). This extends into decisions on 50-50 tackles going the way of the home side, close penalty decisions favoring the home side, reducing the length of/increasing the stoppage time (injury time) based on whether the scoreline is favoring the home-side or not.(aka Fergie time). Studies have also shown that referees at the Stretford End of Old Trafford, home of ManUtd experience spikes in heart rates when turning down a penalty for the home-side. Definitely, this kind of pressure on the referee is bound to play in favour of the side playing at home. Other stadia where referees are very obviously pressured into decisions include the Camp Nou, home to Barcelona FC.

Home advantage? Definitely!

source.b235bd1b:
In 1990, John Beck was appointed manager of Cambridge United. Languishing in the fourth tier of English football, this was a modest club with a squad of committed players with limited technical skills. The club expected Beck to get the team promoted but couldn’t afford the new players necessary to guarantee promotion.
So Beck couldn’t follow the standard rules, he had to change the game to give his players an advantage over better, more skilled players. Beck realised that a physical long-ball game that didn’t rely on finesse would give his team the best chance of winning because finesse players weren’t used to it. The football would be brutal and ugly on the eye – but Beck didn’t care. After all, it’s better to win ugly that lose pretty – the trophy cabinet at Manchester United is bigger than Arsenal’s.
Beck began to find modest success, but observed that one of the problems of punting long balls in to the corners of the pitch for his strikers to run on to was that a large percentage were over-hit. Too many hopefully balls rolled out of a play and gave possession back to the opposition. He struck on an ingenious solution: to not only adjust the playing style to suit his players but adjust the playing environment to shift the odds in his team’s favour. He instructed the groundsman to let the grass grow long in the corners of the pitch so his team’s frequent long balls would be caught up and stay within the touchlines.
The methods drew criticism from outside the club, but nobody could argue with his success. In three seasons he had taken the down-and-out club up to 5th place in the Second Division – the club’s highest ever league position.

source.cc3c1c2e: The home advantage (HA) is a robust phenomenon in football whereby the home team wins more games and scores more goals than the away team. One explanation is that the home crowd spurs on home team performance and causes the referee to unconsciously favour the home team. The Covid-19 (COVID) pandemic provided a unique opportunity to assess this explanation for HA, as European football leagues played part of the 2019/2020 season with crowds present and concluded with crowds absent. Using multi-level modelling we compared team performance and referee decisions pre-COVID (crowd present) and during-COVID (crowd absent) across 4844 games from 15 leagues in 11 countries. HA (goals scored and points gained) was significantly reduced during-COVID, which reflected the inferior performance of the home team. In games without fans, home teams created significantly fewer attacking opportunities and referee-bias was diluted when controlling for the attacking dominance of teams; such that the number of fouls and yellow cards ruled against away sides, while still significant, was reduced and no effects were observed for red cards. Implications for sporting practice and directions for future research are discussed.
